channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: US to pressure Iran over 'plot'
item.description: US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton calls for a "very strong message" to be sent to Iran after allegations of a plot to kill the Saudi ambassador to the US.

item.title: Burma frees political prisoners
item.description: Opposition activists in Burma say the government has freed more than 150 political prisoners as part of a general amnesty.

item.title: EU plans 'greener' farm subsidies
item.description: The European Union announces plans to reform its Common Agricultural Policy, its most expensive scheme, and one of the most controversial.

item.title: Bomb attacks hit Baghdad police
item.description: At least 17 people are killed in a string of car bomb attacks around the Iraqi capital Baghdad, say security officials.

item.title: NZ oil spill ship captain charged
item.description: The captain of a container ship that ran aground off the coast of New Zealand and is leaking fuel oil has been arrested and charged, officials say.

item.title: Australia carbon tax law passed
item.description: Australia's lower house of parliament passes a controversial carbon tax measure, with an upper house vote in favour expected next month.

item.title: Mid-East prisoner swap welcomed
item.description: Israelis and Palestinians take to the streets in celebration over a prisoner exchange deal which will free Israeli soldier Gilad Shalit.

item.title: Jackson 'did not cause own death'
item.description: Michael Jackson could not have given himself the powerful anaesthetic that caused his death, the doctor who performed the singer's autopsy testifies.

item.title: Slovak talks after bailout block
item.description: Political parties in Slovakia are in talks on their next step a day after parliament dramatically rejected plans to expand the EU bailout fund.

item.title: Pro-Assad Syrians throng Damascus
item.description: Tens of thousands of Syrians throng the centre of Damascus in a huge show of support for embattled President Bashar al-Assad.

item.title: China and Vietnam reach sea deal
item.description: China and Vietnam sign an agreement to manage their sometimes bitter maritime dispute over the South China Sea, after months of tension.

item.title: Encephalitis kills 400 in India
item.description: More than 400 people, mainly children, die in an outbreak of water-borne viral encephalitis in northern India, health officials say.

item.title: Zombies hurt in film set accident
item.description: Ambulance crews were faced with an apparently grisly scene after an accident on a Toronto film set, as actors' injuries were made to look far worse because of their zombie costumes.

item.title: Meerkats recognise others' voices
item.description: Meerkats recognise another member of their social group by the sound of their voice, according to scientists.

item.title: Liverpool want breakaway TV deal
item.description: Liverpool say top clubs should be allowed to sell their own overseas television rights, rather than collectively through the Premier League.

item.title: Sportsday Live - Wednesday 12 October
item.description: Sportsday Live - featuring the latest on the government's call for FA reforms, Liverpool's reported desire for a breakaway TV deal and more.

item.title: Government calls for FA reforms
item.description: English football has until March to introduce sweeping changes or else face government intervention into the running of the sport.

item.title: UK unemployment hits 17-year high
item.description: UK unemployment rose by 114,000 between June and August to 2.57 million, a 17-year high, according to official figures.

item.title: 'Wild gossip' about Fox dismissed
item.description: Liam Fox says he will "carry on doing the job I'm meant to do", as a colleague dismisses "wild gossip" about the defence secretary.

item.title: Libya to cost UK £300m, says Fox
item.description: The total cost of UK operations in Libya is likely to be about £300m, Defence Secretary Liam Fox says.

item.title: Force-feeding death mother guilty
item.description: The mother of a 10-month-old girl is found guilty at the Old Bailey of causing her death by force-feeding.

item.title: Tabak jury visits Jo Yeates flat
item.description: The jury in the trial of Vincent Tabak visits the flat where Jo Yeates lived.

item.title: Judge to rule on travellers' site
item.description: A High Court judge is due to rule if the eviction of travellers from Dale Farm in Essex can go ahead.

item.title: Insurers lose asbestos legal case
item.description: Insurance companies fail in a legal bid to scrap the right of people in Scotland to claim damages for an the asbestos-related condition.

item.title: Baby's 'unexplained' death probed
item.description: The death of a nine-month-old baby boy at a house in the north east of Glasgow is being treated as "unexplained", police say.

item.title: Bomb left at Polish couple's home
item.description: A pipe bomb is left on the windowsill of a Polish couple's house in Antrim's Steeple estate.

item.title: PM's Finucane meeting was 'crass'
item.description: Former NI Secretary Shaun Woodward says it was "crass and cruel" to bring Pat Finucane's family to Downing Street to say there would be no independent public inquiry into his muder.

item.title: Big jump in unemployment figures
item.description: A big jump in unemployment in Wales is called "extremely disappointing" by ministers, as the number of jobless hits 131,000.

item.title: University needs 'decent burial'
item.description: The University of Wales needs "a decent burial" after a turbulent period which has damaged the reputation of the nation around the world, the education minister says.

item.title: Republican hopefuls in TV debate
item.description: Republican presidential candidates hold a televised debate, in an encounter seen as a crucial test for the campaign of Texas Governor Rick Perry.

item.title: US Senate passes China yuan bill
item.description: The US Senate votes through a bill which aims to put pressure on China to increase the value of the yuan.

item.title: Hurricane Jova hits Mexico coast
item.description: Hurricane Jova reaches Mexico's Pacific coast, bringing heavy rain and strong winds to tourist resorts and the busy port of Manzanillo.

item.title: Tiny teeth re-write rodent record
item.description: Rodent fossils found in Peru are at least 41 million years old - South America's oldest - and indicate an African origin.

item.title: Liberia election count under way
item.description: Votes are being counted in Liberia's presidential election, with the current incumbent Ellen Johnson Sirleaf and Winston Tubman tipped to be the front-runners.

item.title: Uganda MPs suspend all oil deals
item.description: Uganda's parliament orders President Museveni's government to suspend all oil deals amid claims top officials received multi-million dollar bribes.

item.title: Spanish bank ratings downgraded
item.description: Two leading credit rating agencies downgrade some of Spain's largest banks, citing a deteriorating outlook for the Spanish economy.

item.title: West condemns Tymoshenko jailing
item.description: The EU and US condemn the jailing of former Ukraine leader Yulia Tymoshenko on charges dismissed in the West as politically motivated.

item.title: Egypt minister quits over protest
item.description: Egypt's Finance Minister Hazem el-Beblawi, appointed after the uprising, resigns over the handling of Sunday's bloody protests, officials say.

item.title: Libya NTC head Jalil visits Sirte
item.description: The head of Libya's transitional authority visits the Gaddafi stronghold of Sirte, where NTC troops are battling the few remaining loyalists.

item.title: India monsoon satellite launched
item.description: India successfully launches a new satellite, the Megha-Tropiques, to study monsoon patterns.

item.title: India 'murder policeman' is freed
item.description: The high court in the Indian capital Delhi overturns the conviction of a senior police officer found guilty of murdering an Indian Express journalist.

item.title: Thais race to stop Bangkok floods
item.description: Workers in Thailand race to finish sandbag walls on the outskirts of Bangkok, to try to stop the country's worst floods in years inundating parts of the capital.

item.title: HK to subsidise house purchases
item.description: Hong Kong is to resume a programme to subsidise home purchases after public frustration over sky-high property prices.

item.title: Eurozone production on the rise
item.description: Industrial production in the 17 countries that use the euro rose unexpectedly during August, figures show.

item.title: Sony offers 'smoking' TV checks
item.description: Sony is to offer free safety checks on several of its TVs after a number of them started smoking.

item.title: Republicans block Obama jobs bill
item.description: US Senate Republicans block President Barack Obama's $447bn (£287bn) jobs bill in a procedural vote.

item.title: Blackberry users suffer new crash
item.description: Blackberry users complain of a fresh crash hours after the firm which makes the smartphones, RIM, said all services were "operating normally".

item.title: Sony locks accounts after breach
item.description: Sony locks user accounts on its PlayStation Network and SOE games service after unauthorised sign-in attempts.

item.title: Ultrasound used to heal fractures
item.description: In the city where doctors first pioneered ultrasound the same technology is now being used to treat broken bones.

item.title: Adele leads US music award nods
item.description: British singer Adele leads this year's American Music Awards nominations with four nods, including artist of the year.

item.title: Bardem to play new Bond villain
item.description: The Oscar-winning actor confirms that he will play a villain in the 23rd James Bond film.

item.title: Michael Douglas to play Liberace
item.description: Michael Douglas and Matt Damon are to star in Behind the Candelabra, a movie based on the life of flamboyant musician Liberace.

item.title: Fish film nets documentary prize
item.description: A documentary about the impact of overfishing wins a new award honouring films that make a significant impact on society.

item.title: BP reveals emergency spill plan
item.description: BP draws up contingency plans to tackle an oil spill off Shetland, twice the size of its Deepwater Horizon disaster.

item.title: New marine power sites leased out
item.description: An Edinburgh-based company is among developers who have secured leases for areas of the seabed, including off the Western Isles.

item.title: Veg 'lowers genetic heart risk'
item.description: People who are genetically susceptible to heart disease can lower their risk by eating lots of fruit and raw vegetables, study findings reveal.

item.title: 'First ever' fall in global TB
item.description: Cases and death rates from TB have declined for the first time, says the World Health Organization.

item.title: Gates scheme 'helped prevent HIV'
item.description: About 100,000 people in India may have escaped HIV infection over five years because of a scheme funded by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, a study says.

item.title: Prisoner swap deal to free Shalit
item.description: Israel and Hamas agree a deal to free hundreds of Palestinian prisoners in return for the release of captive Israeli soldier Gilad Shalit, snatched by militants five years ago.

item.title: Is the tide turning against tax havens?
item.description: Campaigners are highlighting the number of companies using tax havens, but with a wave of protests, has the tide turned?

item.title: How to clean an oil-slicked penguin
item.description: Jeremy Gray is among those volunteering at the Oiled Wildlife Response Centre in New Zealand after the Rena oil spill. He explains how to clean rescued wildlife.

item.title: Is it OK to jokily call someone 'bipolar'?
item.description: Terms like "autistic" and "schizophrenic" are often used in jest. But how harmful is it to bandy the names of medical conditions about?

item.title: VIDEO: Afghan opium production rising
item.description: According to a United Nations report, opium production in Afghanistan has risen by 61% this year compared with 2010.

item.title: VIDEO: Guns for Pitt film confiscated
item.description: Nearly 100 guns which were to be used in Brad Pitt's World War Z film have been confiscated because they had not been properly deactivated.

item.title: VIDEO: Uncovering child sacrifice in Uganda
item.description: A BBC investigation has discovered that many cases of child sacrifice in Uganda are not being followed up by the police and little is being done to protect potential victims.

item.title: VIDEO: Naval forces rescue hijacked ship
item.description: British and US naval forces have rescued 23 hostages from an Italian ship hijacked by Somali pirates.

item.title: VIDEO: Kashmir graves to be investigated
item.description: The government in Indian-administered Kashmir has ordered an investigation to determine the identity of nearly 6,000 bodies buried in unmarked graves.

item.title: VIDEO: Antelope brings down cyclist
item.description: Dramatic footage has emerged of a South African mountain biker being knocked off his bike by a charging antelope.

item.title: VIDEO: Spy tactics cause concern in Germany
item.description: Germany's justice minister has called for a national and state level probe into the use of controversial computer software to spy on people.

item.title: VIDEO: Pop art tribute for Amy Winehouse
item.description: Gerald Laing, famous for his pop art images of Brigitte Bardot and Anna Karina, is showcasing a series of Amy Winehouse paintings and drawings in London.

item.title: Is necklacing returning to South Africa?
item.description: Is necklacing - death by burning tyre - returning to South Africa?

item.title: In pictures: 24 hours of news
item.description: A selection of striking images from around the world

item.title: America's commutes start earlier and last longer
item.description: How Americans' commutes are starting earlier and lasting longer

item.title: Timing key to Shalit release deal
item.description: Hamas setbacks gave rise to long-mooted prisoner exchange deal

item.title: The mystery surrounding Kashmir's graves
item.description: Who lies hidden in Kashmir's unmarked graves?

item.title: Is the alcohol message all wrong?
item.description: The radical theory that alcohol does NOT cause bad behaviour

item.title: Breathing new life into the PC
item.description: Evolving the PC for the 21st Century
